What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Conceptualizing data and how it can be understood from a worldly point of view/its intersections with various sectors

In the class Estimation and Error, we approximated confidence intervals for realistic variables. We discussed the history of statistics and the development of the subject through the 19th and 20th century. We observed possible confounding variables in a problem. Towards the end of the course, we discussed applications of statistics in the real world (machine learning, political influence).

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths - facilitated learning by crafting math into something a lot more digestible for non-stem students
Weakness - none

A manner in which the course can be improved is by having a more of a numerical interpretation of the concepts. Strengths of the class include providing an understanding the bias and controversy of statistics and providing knowledge on the background and significance of statistics.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The live lessons worked well but it was hard to maintain discussions, however, the breakout rooms helped a bit

Despite some technological difficulties (minor), the function of course remotely functioned quite well and, with the effort of the professor, no value of the course was lost. What was successful was having guest speakers discuss their personal connection with statistics.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely if you are looking for a QR distributional requirement as a non-stem major this is the class for you

I would recommend another student to enroll in this course. It provides an introduction to the basic understandings statistics and its role/applications. The subjects of the class are fun to learn about and has realistic applications.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
